content.question:
Transposable elements are significant features in the genomes of almost all eukaryotic organisms. The accumulation of these elements in various species can help determine their relatedness. Table 1 indicates the presence (<math alttext="plus" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) or absence (<math alttext="minus" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) of 5 segments of <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that have been moved by transposition (transposons) in 6 primate species.

Table 1. Presence or absence of 5 transposons in primate species

Species

5 

Human

<math alttext="minus" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 

Which of the following best predicts how phylogenetic relationships might be revised if transposon 1 was not found in chimpanzees?

choices.label: Bonobos would be more closely related to humans than to chimpanzees.
Chimpanzees would be more closely related to humans than to bonobos.
Orangutans would be more closely related to humans than to chimpanzees.
Chimpanzees would be more closely related to gibbons than to gorillas.

content.answer: Chimpanzees would be more closely related to humans than to bonobos.

skill.text: 6.E: Predict the causes or effects of a change in, or disruption to, one or more components in a biological system.
